perturbation.original_text: As used in this Agreement, the term "Web site" shall mean a computer system intended to be accessed through the World Wide Web segment of the Internet, including software and content intended to be viewed and/or operated upon by persons accessing the computer system via the Internet. A Web site may exist on a single computer system with other Web sites.
perturbation.changed_text: As used in this Agreement, the term "Web site" shall mean a static collection of HTML pages. A Web site may not exist on a single computer system with other Web sites.
perturbation.explanation: The modified definition of "Web site" restricts its functionality to only static HTML pages, conflicting with the common and legal understanding that a website can include dynamic content, applications, and interactive elements. By stating that a website 'may not exist on a single computer system with other Web sites' introduces a contradiction. Web hosting typically involves multiple sites on one server.
perturbation.law_explanation: Florida Statutes § 815.06 defines computer systems and networks in a way that encompasses dynamic websites and shared hosting environments. By restricting the definition of 'Web site' to a static collection of HTML pages and prohibiting co-existence on a single server, the modified contract language contradicts the broad, inclusive definition used in Florida law, potentially impacting interpretations related to computer crimes and data security.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: Statutes & Constitution :View Statutes : Online Sunshine April 17, 2025 Search Statutes: 2024 2023 2022 2021 2020 2019 2018 2017 2016 2015 2014 2013 2012 2011 2010 2009 2008 2007 2006 2005 2004 2003 2002 2001 2000 1999 1998 1997 Home Senate House Citator Statutes, Constitution, & Laws of Florida Florida Statutes Search Statutes Search Tips Florida Constitution Laws of Florida Legislative & Executive Branch Lobbyists Information Center Joint Legislative Committees & Other Entities Joint Administrative Procedures Committee (JAPC) Joint Committee on Public Counsel Oversight(JCPO) Joint Legislative Auditing Committee (JLAC) Joint Legislative Budget Commission (JLBC) Joint Select Committee on Collective Bargaining (JSCB) Office of Program Policy Analysis & Government Accountability (OPPAGA) Auditor General Commission on Ethics Economic and Demographic Research (EDR) Florida Historic Capitol Historical Committees Florida Legislative Committee on Intergovernmental Relations (LCIR) Joint Legislative Committee on Everglades Oversight (JCEO) Joint Legislative Sunset Committee (JCSC) Florida Government Efficiency Task Force Legislative Employment Legistore Links Select Year: 2024 2023 2022 2021 2020 2019 2018 2017 2016 2015 2014 2013 2012 2011 2010 2009 2008 2007 2006 2005 2004 2003 2002 2001 2000 1999 1998 1997 The Florida Statutes The 2024 Florida Statutes (including 2025 Special Session C) Title XLVI CRIMES Chapter 815 COMPUTER-RELATED CRIMES View Entire Chapter F.S. 815.06 815.06 Offenses against users of computers, computer systems, computer networks, and electronic devices. — (1) As used in this section, the term “user” means a person with the authority to operate or maintain a computer, computer system, computer network, or electronic device. (2) A person commits an offense against users of computers, computer systems, computer networks, or electronic devices if he or she willfully, knowingly, and without authorization or exceeding authorization: (a) Accesses or causes to be accessed any computer, computer system, computer network, or electronic device with knowledge that such access is unauthorized or the manner of use exceeds authorization; (b) Disrupts or denies or causes the denial of the ability to transmit data to or from an authorized user of a computer, computer system, computer network, or electronic device, which, in whole or in part, is owned by, under contract to, or operated for, on behalf of, or in conjunction with another; (c) Destroys, takes, injures, or damages equipment or supplies used or intended to be used in a computer, computer system, computer network, or electronic device; (d) Destroys, injures, or damages any computer, computer system, computer network, or electronic device; (e) Introduces any computer contaminant into any computer, computer system, computer network, or electronic device; or (f) Engages in audio or video surveillance of an individual by accessing any inherent feature or component of a computer, computer system, computer network, or electronic device, including accessing the data or information of a computer, computer system, computer network, or electronic device that is stored by a third party. (3)(a) Except as provided in paragraphs (b) and (c), a person who violates subsection (2) commits a felony of the third degree, punishable as provided in s. 775.082 , s. 775.083 , or s. 775.084 . (b) A person commits a felony of the second degree, punishable as provided in s. 775.082 , s. 775.083
perturbation.justification: The changed contract text's narrow definition of "Web site" as a "static collection of HTML pages" and its prohibition of co-existence on a single server creates a potential contradiction with Florida Statutes § 815.06. While the statute itself does not explicitly define 'website', it addresses offenses against 'computer systems' and 'computer networks'. The changed text's limitation of a website's capabilities and hosting arrangements could impact the statute's application, potentially creating a contradiction in interpreting computer-related crimes or security breaches involving websites, as the definition provided in the contract is much more restrictive than what is usually encompassed by the term 'computer system'. The limitation on co-existence on a single server also contradicts the common understanding of how websites are typically hosted. The degree of contradiction isn't complete (1.0) because the statute doesn't directly define 'website', so this creates an interpretive issue.

perturbation.original_text: i-on will maintain the operation of the Hosted Site continuously, twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week, including holidays, with the exception of reasonable hardware and software maintenance that must be performed on the Hosting Computer and/or the Hosted Site. i-on will use best efforts to schedule and perform such maintenance between the hours of 8pm and 8am Eastern Standard Time on weekdays, or during weekends.
perturbation.changed_text: i-on will attempt to maintain the Hosted Site during business hours, Monday through Friday, excluding holidays, with no commitment to uptime. i-on will decide when and how to perform maintenance.
perturbation.explanation: The original contract specifies continuous operation with scheduled maintenance. The modified version significantly reduces the service commitment and removes guaranteed uptime, contradicting typical web hosting service level expectations and implied obligations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) - Implied Warranty of Merchantability
perturbation.law_explanation: By significantly reducing the uptime commitment and removing any guarantee of continuous service, the modified text potentially violates the implied warranty of merchantability under the UCC, which suggests that goods (and, by extension, services) should be fit for their intended purpose. A web hosting service with no guaranteed uptime might be considered unfit, particularly for business customers relying on continuous online presence.
perturbation.justification: The modified text significantly reduces the uptime commitment, removing any guarantee of continuous service. The Law Explanation argues this potentially violates the implied warranty of merchantability under the UCC, suggesting the service might be unfit for its intended purpose. Although there are no Scraped Law Snippets provided to confirm the UCC's specifics on implied warranty of merchantability, the drastic shift from continuous operation to operation only during business hours with no uptime commitment suggests a weakening of the service's fitness, thus creating a noticeable contradiction. The absence of law snippets weakens the claim, thus the moderate score.

perturbation.original_text: The Customer is solely responsible for all content on the Hosted Site, including but not limited to, HTML pages, graphics, sounds, animations, video clips, Java applets, client-site scripts such as JavaScript and VBScript features, ActiveX controls, and other files and/or executable components for use or download by the users of the Hosted Site, as well as the accuracy and validity of any information or data contained within, as well as the overall look-and-feel of the Hosted Site from a user's perspective.
perturbation.changed_text: The Customer assumes no responsibility for illegal content hosted on the site, even if placed there by the Customer. I-on is responsible for monitoring and policing the content hosted on the Customer's site.
perturbation.explanation: By stating the customer assumes no responsibility for illegal content and that the web hosting company is wholly responsible creates a direct conflict with federal laws regarding content liability.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 18 U.S. Code § 2252 - Certain activities relating to material constituting or containing child pornography
perturbation.law_explanation: 18 U.S. Code § 2252 outlines federal laws regarding child pornography and other illegal content. While web hosting providers can face liability, the primary responsibility for the content resides with the website owner. This modification attempts to absolve the customer of responsibility for illegal content, which is against the law.

Certain activities relating to material involving the sexual exploitation of minors (a) Any person who- (1) knowingly transports or ships using any means or facility of interstate or foreign commerce or in or affecting interstate or foreign commerce by any means including by computer or mails, any
perturbation.justification: The changed text directly contradicts the legal principle that website owners are primarily responsible for the content they host, even if illegal. The changed text states "The Customer assumes no responsibility for illegal content hosted on the site, even if placed there by the Customer." This directly contrasts with 18 U.S. Code § 2252, which establishes liability for activities related to material involving the sexual exploitation of minors, implying that website owners can be held accountable for such content. While the snippet focuses on child exploitation, the broader principle is that individuals are responsible for illegal content they facilitate. The original text placed the burden on the customer, while the modified text shifts it entirely to the hosting provider, creating a strong contradiction of established liability principles, leading to a high contradiction score.
